The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  launched  the  Education 
Sector  Program  (ESP)  cluster  in  2006  to  support  the  preparation 
and  implementation  of  the  school  sector  reform  (SSR)  program. 
The  ESP  adopted  a  program  cluster  approach  to  phase  ADB 
assistance.  Three  subprograms  were  envisioned  in  accordance 
with the time frame and progress of SSR from 2007 onward. The 
ESP subprogram I, approved on 1 December 2006, supports the 
Nepal Education for All (EFA) program (2004–2009) for basic and 
primary  education  (grades  1–5)  with  a  program  loan  for  $30 
million from FY2007 to FY2009. A capacity development grant of 
$2  million  complements  the  ESP  subprogram  I  to  develop 
government stakeholders’ capacity in policy analysis, formulation, 
and coordination. It also supports the preparation of an SSR core 
document.  The  ESP  subprogram  II,  approved  on  24  January 
2008,  supports  the  preparation  and  transition  to  SSR  from 
FY2008 to FY2011, in particular a model-building exercise of the 
basic education extension to grades 1–8 in a few districts, as well 
as broad capacity development for system readiness. 

The  ESP  subprogram  III  is  proposed  to  support  the  Government 
in  the  implementation  of  the  SSR  program  from  2009  onward. 
Subprogram  III  will  cover  the  period  from  FY2010  to  FY2012, 
during which the Government will focus on the implementation of 
basic  education  restructuring,  while  model  building  activities  will 
be  initiated  for  secondary  education  and  technical  education  and 
vocational training (TEVT).

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC AND POLITICAL CONTEXT 

2. 
Nepal, with per capita income of about $447 (FY2009), is the poorest country in South 
Asia. Key development challenges include widespread poverty (31% in 2004) and high income 
inequality (Gini coefficient of 41.1% in 2004).  

3. 
Nepal’s  recent  economic  development  has  been  modest.  The  difficult  political 
environment for reforms and development activities resulted in annual average gross domestic 
product  (GDP)  growth  of  4.1%  during  FY2004–FY2009.  This  growth  was  underpinned  by  a 
generally  stable  macroeconomic  situation.  The  improved  security  situation  after  2006  mainly 
benefited the growth of services, which surpassed the relatively slow growth in agriculture and 
industries.  The  fiscal  deficit  was  contained,  at  an  average  of  1.5%  of  GDP  over  FY2004–
FY2009, while strong remittances inflow and tourism receipts helped maintain a surplus current 
account  throughout  the  period,  except  in  FY2007.  Overall  average  inflation  over  FY2004–
FY2009 was at about 7%.  

Aided  by  the  improved  security  situation,  overall  GDP  growth  increased  from  3.3%  in 
4. 
FY2007 to 5.3% in FY2008, but slowed down to 4.7% in FY2009. Given its limited exposure to 
the global financial system, the global economic slowdown is expected to have limited impact on 
Nepal. However, some impact may be inevitable on exports, remittances, tourism receipts, and 
external assistance, especially if the global recession is prolonged. In view of this, GDP growth 
is forecast to slow further to 3.5% in FY2010. Average consumer inflation jumped up to 13% in 
FY2009 from 7.7% a year earlier.  

5. 
Improved  revenue  mobilization  helped  contain  the  budget  deficit  at  1.9%  of  GDP  in 
FY2009 despite a surge in expenditure. Total spending swelled by 15%, mainly because of the 
peace  process,  resulting  in  an  improved  project  implementation  environment.  Total  revenue 
grew robustly by 18% in FY2009 supported by stronger tax administration. It increased to 18% 
of  GDP,  a  gain  of  about  2.7  percentage  points  from  a  year  earlier.  Continued  successful 
improvements  in  revenue  collection  and  sustained  support  from  development  partners  will  be 
the key to maintaining macroeconomic stability.  

6. 
On the political front, the end of the conflict in 2006 and the improved security situation 
have  opened  up  the  “development  space,”  facilitating  revival  of  development  activities.  The 
peace process has since progressed, with orderly conduct of the historic Constituent Assembly 
election  in  April  2008  and  the  installation  of  an  elected  coalition  government  led  by  the 
Communist  Party  of  Nepal  (Maoist)  in  August  2008.  However,  the  fragility  of  the  democratic 
process  was  proven  by  the  quickly  deteriorating  situation  following  a  political  standoff  with 
respect  to  the  integration  of  soldiers.  Following  the  withdrawal  of  key  coalition  partners,  the 
Prime  Minister  resigned  on  4  May  2009.  A  new  coalition  government  led  by  the  Communist 
Party  of  Nepal  (Unified Marxist-Leninist)  was  subsequently  formed.  Without  the  support  of  the 
Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist), the inclusiveness of the political process remains limited.  

7. 
A key mandate of the new government is to facilitate drafting a new and more inclusive 
constitution that will also define the structure and substance of a new federal republic state, the 
decision  on  which  was  taken  by  the  first  session  of  the  601-member  Constituent  Assembly  in 
May  2008,  abolishing  the  centuries-old  monarchy.  The  process  has  begun  but  progress  has 
been  impeded  by  some  major  political  hitches.  The  constitution  drafting  process  involves  the 
daunting task of addressing deep-rooted and divisive issues of ethnicity, regionalism, caste, and

12. 
Participation  in  education  has  expanded  at  all  levels,  resulting  in  substantial  growth  of 
the  education  system.  In  2008,  the  gross  enrollment  rate  (GER)  for  ECED  reached  63.4%.

8.0% in 2001. As primary education enrollment has reached 91.9% and primary completion has

2008.

Education for All Program 

21. 
The Government has a high commitment to education, as reflected in successive Five-

increase  equity  in  access  to  education.  Social  inclusion  is  a  central  approach  to  reduce 
disparities in education in terms of gender, caste, and ethnicity. The decentralization of school 
management  responsibilities  to  SMCs,  and  community  participation  in  education  are  at  the 
center of the Government’s strategy to improve the quality and efficiency of education. In 2000,

contributed to sector outcomes in primary education. Appendix 3 reports progress on key EFA 
outcome  indicators.  It  has  also  made  progress  in  implementation  strategies  such  as 
decentralization, capacity development, financial management, and institutional harmonization.

2. 

School Sector Reform Program 

26. 
To  build  on  the  achievements  of  EFA,  and  address  some  of  the  shortcomings  and 
constraints, the Government has developed the school sector reform (SSR) program. The SSR 
program envisions a transition from the current subsector approach, with education financed by 
programs  such  as  EFA  and  the  Secondary  Education  Support  Program  (SESP), 10  to  an 
integrated  program  approach.  SSR  aims  to  restructure  the  primary  and  secondary  school 
system into an integrated grade 1–12 system in a phased manner. The Government recognizes 
that 5 years of basic education is not sufficient and intends to extend basic education coverage 
to grades 1–8 and integrate secondary education into grades 9–12. It also intends to improve 
synergies  between  basic  education  and  secondary  education  to  achieve  a  more  holistic 
approach  to  school  education.  The  SSR  program  is  partly  a  continuation  of  earlier  programs

In accordance with the Interim Constitution, SSR guarantees free basic education to all

affirmative  actions  to  support  education  for  girls  and  disadvantaged  groups  has  been  defined. 
SSR intends to provide multiple educational choices to schools and communities with regard to 
learning content, medium of instruction, learning materials, and delivery methods. Strategies to 
improve  the  relevance  of  education  to  local  needs  include  multigrade  teaching  and  the 
development and teaching of local content curriculum.

28.

9–12. Guidelines for teacher development have been developed.

3. 
A  recent  country  assistance  program  evaluation21 of  ADB’s  support  to  the  education 
56. 
sector in Nepal found that ADB assistance to the EFA program in primary education using the 
PBA  has  so  far  been  successful.  ADB’s  adoption  of  the  PBA  significantly  improved  portfolio 
management  and  fund  disbursements  in  the  education  sector  while  the  program  cluster 
approach  provided  continuity  and  timeliness  of  ADB  support.  The  Government  benefited  from

and resulted in strengthening the core functions of MOE. Cost-efficiency was likewise achieved

57. 
Areas  for  improvement  identified  by  the  country  assistance  program  evaluation  include 
the  need  to  improve  the  internal  efficiency  of  the  education  system  by  addressing  the  high 
primary  education  repetition  rate  and  high  dropout  rate,  as  well  as  improving  quality.  An  area 
that will also require attention is the need to strengthen the planning and predictability of capital 
budgeting  to  address  the  growing  demand  for  classrooms  caused  by  the  rapid  growth  in 
enrollment  during  the  last  few  years.  The  unevenness  in  the  capacity  of  local  education 
authorities and schools also remains a concern. Further, there is a need for greater functional 
clarity  and  an  accountability  mechanism  between  districts  and  schools  to  ensure  effective 
education  service  provision  in  the  new  decentralized  context.  Establishment  of  the  EPC  and 
MOE’s  commitment  to  implement  its  decentralization  policy  contributed  to  the  effectiveness  of 
the  education  sector.  The  country  assistance  program  evaluation  recommended  that  ADB 
continue  using  the  PBA  and  continue  to  assist  the  Government  in  developing  and  expanding

V. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Program Benefits and Impacts 

117.  Economic  benefits.  Three  distinct  economic  benefits  can  be  identified  as  a  potential 
result of the SSR program: (i) increased access to education, resulting in more workers in the 
future  with  at  least  8  years  of  schooling  and  with  higher  earnings  as  a  result;  (ii)  enhanced 
education  quality  and  relevance,  resulting  in  higher  productivity  and  earnings  on  the  part  of 
everyone  who  has  completed  basic  education;  and  (iii)  improved  internal  efficiency  in  the 
education system.  

118.  For  basic  education,  item  (i)  will  result  in  a  total  of  300,484  additional  students 
completing  basic  school  education  in  Nepal’s  public  schools  over  the  5  years  of  the  program 
being appraised. As for item (ii), regression analysis suggests that increased quality may result 
in a 5% increase of the average annual earnings of those with basic education.  

119.  To  measure  a  change  in  item  (iii),  education’s  internal  efficiency,  the  analysis  required 
an estimation of the number of student-years needed to produce a student who completes basic 
education. In a perfectly efficient 8-year system, with no repetition and no dropout, all children 
entering grade 1 would finish the course 8 years later. However, it currently takes an average of 
11.5 student-years for a student to complete the 8-year basic education course, so 3.5 years of 
the  11.5  years  (the  costs  of  which  must  be  covered  from  the  budget)  are  in  a  sense  wasted 
years.  Given  the  assumed  reductions  in  repetition  and  dropout  rates  as  a  result  of  the  SSR 
program, by the end of the full 7 years of reform, it is anticipated that it will take only 9.73 years 
on  average  for  a  student  to  complete  basic  education.  Appendix  6  contains  the  summary 
economic and financial analysis, while Supplementary Appendix C contains the economic and 
financial analysis. 

120.  Social benefits and poverty impact. The ESP subprogram III will also generate social 
benefits  among  the  socially  and  economically  disadvantaged.  Better  access  to  an  affordable 
and quality education, and better learning achievements will ensure that these groups are able 
to  generate  the  necessary  human  and  social  capital  to  build  economically  and  socially 
responsible lives. A shift to an egalitarian and inclusive education system will help to relieve the 
root causes of conflict and social tension, build social cohesion, and contribute to social stability. 
Improved access to postprimary and basic education for girls and women will enhance women’s 
roles in the political, economic, and social spheres. Successful implementation of SSR is closely 
linked to the process of peace building in the country. Investment in education in Nepal, in the 
wake  of  signing  of  the  Comprehensive  Peace  Agreement,  is  considered  a  key  measure  of 
conflict prevention.

B. 

Program Risks 

121.  Macroeconomic  risks.  Macroeconomic  stability  and  sustained  economic  growth  are 
crucial for the Government to be able to allocate sufficient recurrent budget to education. In the 
current  macroeconomic  environment,  funding  for  education  should  not  be  compromised.  The 
Government  has  accorded  high  priority  to  the  education  sector  and  has  committed  to  ensure 
that  adequate  funding  will  continue  to  be  allocated  to  the  SSR  program.  Similarly,  continued 
commitment and cooperation from development partners will be crucial for the sustainability of 
SSR.  However,  this  risk  is  considered  minimal,  as  existing  development  partners  have  a  long 
history  of  assisting  education  in  Nepal,  and  new  development  partners  have  tentatively 
expressed interest in providing support to the SSR program. If budget cuts are necessary, the 
Government  intends  to  phase  the  pace  of  reform  in  line  with  the  budget  availability.  Key 
priorities  (such  as  the  provision  of  free  basic  education)  will  continue  to  be  the  focus  of  the 
program, while other components (such as secondary education reform, construction activities, 
teacher qualification upgrading, and other activities that can be implemented independently) will 
be phased or scaled down in line with the available funding. Development partners will have the 
opportunity to review the SSR implementation plan on an annual basis with the submission of 
the ASIP and AWPB. 
122.  Fiduciary  risks.  A  recently  updated  public  expenditure  and  financial  accountability 
assessment30 assessed  that  Nepal’s overall  fiduciary  risk  level  remains  high.  It  concluded  that 
(i)  the  quality  of  the  legal  and  regulatory  framework  for  public  financial  management  and 
procurement  in  Nepal  ranks  among  the  best  in  Asia,  (ii)  implementation  of  that  framework  is 
problematic,  and  (iii)  development  partner  practices  tend  to  reinforce  rather  than  tackle 
implementation weaknesses. However, the financial management arrangements outlined in the 
JFA  assist  the  Government  in  addressing  public  financial  management  weaknesses  while 
reducing the overall risk level to an acceptable level. The JFA and GAAP adopted under SSR 
further strengthen fiduciary oversight mechanisms and reduce the risk of corruption.  

123.  Political  risks.  While  the  scope  for  a  more  conducive  political  environment  has 
improved  since  the  end  of  the  conflict  in  2006,  peace  building  and  reconstruction  continue  to 
constitute  a  fragile  process  that  entails  political  risks.  Delay  in  development  of  the  new 
constitution could slow down the decentralization plans for the education sector and the transfer 
of authority to the local level. As a risk mitigation measure, the system will continue to operate 
under current implementation arrangements. Moreover, the education sector and the envisioned 
reforms have broad political support. The security situation in some parts in the country remains 
a  difficulty  in  the  delivery  of  education  services,  and  the  democratic  process  remains  fragile. 
Delivery  of  education  services  in  the  Terai  (lowlands)  is  particularly  affected.  Nevertheless, 
successful  implementation  of  the  ongoing  programs  has  demonstrated  the  resilience  of  the 
education system under adverse circumstances. 

124.  Program risks. As SSR is a major reform program, resistance to change from within the 
system,  as  well  as  outside  the  system,  could  be  expected.  Vested  interests  and  dissenting 
opinions may slow down or divert the reform process. This risk has been mitigated throughout 
the  design  process  by  seeking  wide  stakeholder  feedback  and  inputs,  and  the  process  is 
supported at a high political level through cabinet approval of the SSR core document. As such, 
strong opposition to the required changes in the education act is not expected.

Successive  governments  have  given  high  priority  to  education,  particularly  to  meet  the

2. 

Overall Sector Outcomes  

4. 
Consistent  efforts  to  support  education,  social  inclusion  policies,  and  decentralization 
strategies  have  contributed  significantly  to  expand  participation  in  education  at  all  levels.  As 
primary education enrollment has reached more than 90%, and primary completion has reached 
about  76%,  demand  for  postprimary  education  has  increased.  From  2001  to  2008,  the  net 
enrollment  rate  (NER)  for  primary  education  rose  from  81%  to  92%.  The  NER  for  lower 
secondary education rose from 42.9% to 52.3%, while the NER for secondary education grew 
from 29.5% to 34.7%. The NER for higher secondary education was 11% in 2008. The average 
annual growth rate was about 3.5% for primary enrollment, 2.4% for lower secondary, and 7.4% 
for secondary from 2001 to 2006. Gender parity has improved, with girls representing 49.5% of 
primary enrollment, 48.2% of lower secondary enrollment, and 47.2% of secondary enrollment 
in 2008 according to the 2008 Flash I Report.1 Although enrollment rates of Dalits and Janajatis 
have  not  been  systematically  tracked  until  very  recently,  available  data  indicate  that  the 
enrollment of these groups has increased substantially over the past 5 years. Nevertheless, 
gender, caste, and ethnic disparities in enrollment increase with the level of education. Poverty 
remains a major barrier in access to education of the most disadvantaged groups.  

Improving internal efficiency of the public school system, especially in the early grades 
5. 
of  primary  education,  remains  a  challenge.  The  grade  1  gross  intake  rate  was  148%  in  2008, 
reflecting  substantial  underage  and  overage  enrollment.  This  creates  overcrowding  of 
classrooms  and  impedes  the  pedagogical  process.  In  turn,  it  becomes  a  factor  for  high 
repetition  and  dropout  rates.  Repetition  rates  have  slightly  improved  since  2001,  but  28%  of 
grade 1 children repeated the year in 2008. The survival rate to grade 5 was 73% in 2008, and 
the transition rate to lower secondary was 77%. The SLC pass rate for students from community 
schools has ranged from 25% to 35% over the past decade. In 2006, SLC pass rates recorded 
a  net  improvement  of  62%  over  the  previous  year.  However,  90%  of  private  school  students 
pass SLC examinations as opposed to 51% of public school students in 2007. 

6. 
Students’ learning outcomes are difficult to assess in the absence of a reliable learning 
achievement test. However, student achievement in primary and lower secondary education is 
found  to  be  weak.    Comparison  between  a  national  assessment  conducted  in  2008  and  a 
previous  assessment  in  1999  show  continued  weakness  in  Mathematics  and  English,  relative 
strength in Social Studies, and a decline in Nepali mean scores. The 2008 national assessment 
showed that grade 5 students master less than half of the material specified in the curriculum 
framework specifications grid for each grade and subject area, and 16% of the sampled schools 
had  achievement  levels  below  30%.  There  were  also  significant  variations  between  students 
from  different  socioeconomic  and  ethnic  groups—indicating  that  the  education  system  did  not 
compensate for differences in geographical, social, and economic backgrounds. 

7. 
Overall,  Nepal  has  been  successful  in  steadily  improving  access  to  education  at  all 
levels  while  narrowing  gender  and  social  disparities  in  enrollment.  However,  low  internal 
efficiency  and  indication  of  poor  learning  outcomes  suggest  that  further  effort  is  needed  to 
improve the quality of education, and to address the needs of the most disadvantaged groups. 
The  education  divide  persists  between  urban,  rural,  and  remote  areas  as  well  as  between 
children from well-off and less well-off families.

children,  contributed  to  increased  enrollment  among  these  groups.  However,  performance, 
particularly  of  the  Dalits,  needs  attention  as  their  pass  rates  and  promotion  rates  are  low. 
Gender  and  socioeconomic  gaps  widen  markedly  in  the  transition  from  grade  5  to  lower 
secondary.  These  trends  suggest  that  more  assertive  targeting  and  a  comprehensive  support 
program are needed to improve the retention, progress, and academic achievement of children 
from  disadvantaged  groups.  This  would,  in  turn,  help  improve  the  internal  efficiency  of  the 
system.  Factors  typically  affecting  schooling  of  marginalized  children  are  a  combination  of 
poverty, gender, and caste-related social barriers; and academic support that is not sufficiently 
adjusted  to  their  language  and  culture.  Therefore,  a  combination  of  various  strategic 
interventions  is  needed,  most  of  which  have  been  already  introduced  under  the  system:  (i) 
scholarships and other incentive schemes, (ii) deployment of female teachers and teachers from 
disadvantaged  groups,  and  (iii)  mother  tongue  instruction  in  the  early  grades.  Special  support 
for  early  grades  teaching  and  systematic  academic  support  to  disadvantaged  students  would 
help  sustain  enrollment  and  average  learning  outcomes.  This  would  include  special  remedial 
programs for overage grade 1 children to join the age-appropriate classroom. Strict enforcement 
of the policy of non-enrollment of underage children at grade 1 would also help improve grade 1 
efficiency. 

11. 
Quality. Key factors affecting school quality are (i) poor learning environment, including 
overcrowded  classrooms  in  some  areas;  (ii)  lack  of  sufficient  number  of  qualified  teachers; 
(iii) late  delivery  of  textbooks;  (iv)  insufficient  teacher  support  and  supervision,  which  lead  to 
poor pedagogical process and low teacher motivation; (v) rigid instructional provision that does 
not  take  into  account  the  needs  of  a  socioculturally  diverse  population;  and  (vi)  weak 
management  and  monitoring  capacity  at  school  and  district  level.  A  comprehensive  Technical 
Review  of  School  Education2 conducted  in  2006  indicated  that  on  average  54%  of  students 
received a full set of textbooks and 3% a partial set within the first week of the school session. 
In terms of physical facilities, 76% of the schools had drinking water and 78% had toilet facilities; 
36% of the schools had separate toilets for girls.  

The increase in the number of teachers has not kept pace with the increase in student 
12. 
enrollments.  Many  schools  have  insufficient  teachers,  both  in  terms  of  reaching  a  minimum 
teacher per school ratio and reaching subject teacher norms set by the Government. Of greater 
concern  is  the  regional  imbalance  in  the  distribution  of  teachers.  While  about  half  of  the 
mountain and hill districts suffer from severe teacher shortages, the rest have vacancy levels of 
10% or less, or even surpluses. While many valley districts have surpluses, almost all districts in

13. 
Under  SSR,  the  aspiration  and  pressure  of  achieving  the  goal  of  free  and  compulsory 
basic education might drive access to grades 1–8 faster than the internal mechanisms for policy 
formulation  and  strategic  planning  for  improving  quality  can  absorb.  As  access  to  grades  6–8 
will increase faster than access to grades 1–5, the tradeoff between mass access and average 
quality at upper primary education has serious potential. Evaluations of past primary education 
projects  and  programs  also  acknowledged  the  slow  progress  in  the  quality  of  education 
compared  to  the  rapid  expansion  in  access.  Key  steps  needed  to  pursue  the  quality  agenda 
would be to (i) develop a clear framework of norms and standards for quality, including technical 
standards  for  school  inputs,  instructional  processes,  and  outcomes;  (ii) identify  reliable 
instruments  to  measure  cognitive  learning  outcomes;  (iii)  further  analyze  and  develop  a 
comprehensive plan for qualification upgrade, selection, recruitment, and management of basic 
education  teachers;  and  (iv)  develop  implementation  strategies  for  quality  improvement  that 
would rely on incentives and an accountability mechanism, particularly at the local level.   

2. 

Secondary Education and Technical Education and Vocational Training  

14. 
For  decades,  apart  from  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  a  few  bilateral 
agencies,  the  Government  and  most  education  development  partners  have  considered 
secondary  education  as  a  subsector  to  be  addressed  only  after  achieving  universal  primary 
education.  When  SSR  shifted  the  strategic  focus  from  primary  to  basic  education  and 
introduced the concept of an integrated grade 1–12 system, secondary education began to be 
viewed  as  a  necessary  extension  and  upgrading  of  basic  education.  However,  policy  choices 
for secondary education are more complex than for basic education. Thus, careful analysis of 
the implication of such policy choices would be required before implementation of secondary 
education restructuring will begin under SSR. 

15. 
Secondary education financing. The Interim Constitution, enacted in 2007, states that 
free secondary education will be provided by the state. However, at present, secondary schools 
collect  tuition.  In  the  case  of  community  schools,  students  pay  NRs500  or  more  per  year 
whereas institutional lower secondary and secondary schools collect NRs4,000–NRs12,000 or 
NRs6,000–NRs12,000  per  year  per  student  depending  on  the  institution.  In  addition,  each 
school  collects  various  kinds  of  fees  for  extracurricular  activities  such  as  sports  and  special 
training,  as  well  as  for  maintenance  of  facilities  such  as  libraries  and  laboratories.  Moreover, 
community  unaided  schools  currently  receive  only  partial  support  from  the  Government,  so 
communities contribute to teacher salaries and operational costs. Although recent data on the 
share of household and community contribution to secondary education are not available, it is 
anticipated that such a cost-sharing mechanism for secondary education may need to continue 
to  maintain  the  current  system.  It  also  means  that  the  plan  for  further  expanding  secondary 
education will require a more careful and comprehensive sector financing plan.  

Quality.  Expansion of secondary education has significant cost implications in terms of

Minimum  service  standards  for  secondary  education  are  to  be  more  specific  in  terms  of 
curriculum and textbooks, number of subject teachers with appropriate qualifications, education 
facilities  such  as  libraries  and  laboratories,  equipment,  instructional  materials,  and  processes. 
The  Secondary  Education  Support  Project3 also  showed  the  importance  of  hostel  facilities  in 
schools in remote areas. Therefore, a national framework of norms and standards will need to

17. 
Since  the  National  Curriculum  Framework  (grades  1–12)  was  approved  in  2006,  lower 
secondary  and  secondary  curricula  and  textbooks  have  been  revised.  The  new  curricula  are 
more  functional  and  accentuate  problem-solving  approaches  based  on  practical  needs. 
However,  in  terms  of  teacher  skills,  there  is  a  mismatch  between  learning  needs, 
competencies,  and  skills  demanded  from  students  in  the  modern  economy  and  the  teaching 
skills  of  Nepal’s  secondary  teachers.  Teacher  shortages  negatively  affect  the  quality  of 
secondary  education  and  create  a  barrier  to  expansion  of  access  to  secondary  education. 
Comprehensive policies to attract and retain high-quality secondary education teachers should 
be  devised.  Such  policies  should  factor  in  remuneration,  professional  development  issues, 
teacher deployment and class size policies, and accountability systems. 

Higher  secondary  education.  Currently,  there  are  community  higher  secondary 
18. 
schools, private higher secondary schools, and public higher secondary programs affiliated with 
universities.  In  2006,  the  Government  amended  the  Education  Act  and  the  Higher  Secondary 
Education  Act  with  the  intention  of  integrating  higher  secondary  education  with  the  school 
system.  Implementation  of  this  policy  has  been  slow,  and  secondary  education  and  higher 
secondary  education  are  still  managed  by  two  separate  agencies—the  DOE  and  the  Higher 
Secondary  Education  Board.  This  split  has  contributed  to  poor  coordination  between  the  two 
levels.  The  phasing  out  of  the  public  higher  secondary  programs  from  the  universities,  when 
higher  secondary  education  merges  with  the  school  system,  will  add  complexity  in  secondary 
education  restructuring.  As  higher  secondary  schools  have  been  traditionally  established  and 
funded by nongovernment funds, the status and financing of higher secondary education will be 
subject  to  much  debate  in  SSR.  To  date,  the  Government  has  not  established  any  higher 
secondary schools, and has not supplied teachers to higher secondary schools, but it has been 
providing  a  limited  amount  of  grants  for  teachers’  salaries  to  community  higher  secondary 
schools.  

Technical  education  and  vocational  training.  Nepal has a long history of TEVT—
19. 
both school-based and as an independent stream. Higher technical education is provided by the 
universities. More sector-specific training programs are offered by different sector departments 
such  as  cottage  and  small  industries  and  tourism.  Excluding  the  universities,  there  is  an 
estimated national training capacity of about 50,000 trainees annually. The school-based TEVT 
began in 1971, with the expectation to develop students’ marketable skills upon completion of 
school  education.  However,  this  program  could  not  be  sustained  and  the  concept  of  trade 
schools under CTEVT was developed. Some schools are developed as annex schools affiliated 
with CTEVT. Currently, such annexes have 798 students in total.  

20. 
The parallel provision of vocational subjects in schools is not yielding the desired results 
for  several  reasons:  (i)  inadequate  and  outdated  skills  of  graduates;  (ii)  limited  and  restrictive 
choices  of  vocational  subjects;  (iii)  inadequate  preparedness  and  limited  workshop  facilities  in 
the  schools,  with  inadequate  maintenance  and  replacement  of  teaching  equipment;  (iv)  very 
limited  interaction  with  the  private  sector;  (v)  inadequate  number  of  teachers  with  hands-on 
skills;  and  (vi) inadequate  funding  for  recurrent  expenditures.  The  cost  of  providing  TEVT  in 
schools  is  quite  prohibitive—annual  learning  costs  could  be  less  than  NRs10,000  for  general 
school education but as high as NRs100,000 per student for TEVT. This suggests that school-
based TEVT that involves extensive investment in physical infrastructure, equipment, and highly 
specialized technical teachers is not an adequate option in Nepal. A more limited but relevant 
role  of  TEVT  in  school  education  will  be  explored  under  SSR—i.e.,  the  development  of  soft 
employability skills to prepare for and orient schoolchildren toward future employment.

SUMMARY ECONOMIC AND FINANCIAL ANALYSIS 

1. 
This appendix provides an economic rationale for investing in the school sector reform 
(SSR) program. It analyzes the financial and budgetary affordability of the program, and projects 
the sustainability of the education system beyond the SSR program period. 1 

A.  

Economic Analysis of SSR 

2. 
The economic analysis of the initial 5 years of the SSR program compares the benefits 
and costs of the SSR program as opposed to the counterfactual or "without-program" scenario 
in  which  the  Government  of  Nepal’s  program  for  the  school  sector  is  an  extrapolation  of  the 
spending  and  activities  of  the  recent  period  during  which  Education  for  All  (EFA)  was  being 
implemented. The SSR investment being appraised is the estimated addition to sector spending 
(both development and recurrent spending) caused by implementation of the SSR program. The 
benefits are taken to be those changes in the quantity and quality of education produced over 
the period of the program as a result of SSR, as well as any savings attributable to reductions in 
“wastage” (repetition and dropout) of students in the system. Underlying all of the analysis are 
projections of (i) Nepal’s 5-year-old age cohorts2, (ii) gross intake ratios of children into grade 1, 
and (iii) repetition and dropout rates in all grades (1–12).   

1. 

Benefits of School Sector Reform Program 

Three  distinct  benefits  as  a  result  of  SSR  can  be  identified  and  will,  to  the  extent 
3. 
possible,  be  quantified:  (i) increased  education  quantity  (increased  access  to  education, 
resulting  in  more  workers  in  the  future  with  at  least  8  years  of  schooling  and  with  higher 
earnings as a result); (ii) enhanced education quality and relevance (more learning, resulting in 
higher productivity and earnings on the part of everyone who has completed basic education); 
and (iii) enhanced education’s internal efficiency (less “wastage,” i.e., fewer school dropouts and 
repeaters, and lower unit costs as a result).   

4. 
Increased  education  quantity. SSR will result in more children entering the education 
system, who will repeat and drop out less. As a result, more students will complete basic and 
secondary education. Based on higher intake rates and lower repetition and dropout rates, over 
the 5-year period, SSR will result in 300,397 more students completing basic education (grade 8) 
in Nepal’s public schools, and 47,387 more secondary education graduates.

A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy  

Education  plays  a  vital  role  in  human  development  and  hence  contributes  to  poverty  reduction.  In  Nepal,  education  is 
considered a major means for poor households to escape from poverty. With external assistance, Nepal has made significant 
efforts in the education sector, and this has contributed to improvements in human development indicators. The Government’s 
commitment to the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) has also stimulated more effort in improving the primary education 
sector,  with  the  goal  of  achieving  basic  and  primary  education  for  all  by  2015.  Participation  in  education  has  improved 
considerably  over  the  last  5  decades,  especially  at  primary  level.  In  2008,  the  primary  net  enrollment  rate  reached  91.9%, 
compared with 81% in 2001. However, high repetition and dropout rates and poor learning outcomes, especially among girls 
and socioeconomically disadvantaged groups (including indigenous and ethnic minority groups), are major concerns.  
Building  on  the  poverty  reduction  strategy  of  the  Tenth  Plan  (2002–2007),a  the  Government's  Three-Year  Interim  Plan 
(FY2008-FY2010)b  aims  to  build  self-sustaining  societies  free  from  absolute  poverty  through  economic  and  social 
transformation  based  on  social  justice.  Education  is  a  key  priority  sector  of  the  Government  for  overall  development  and 
poverty reduction. The long-term vision of the plan on education is to ensure access of all citizens to inclusive, equitable, and 
quality basic education. The plan emphasizes social inclusion in terms of gender, caste, and ethnicity in education to reduce 
socioeconomic disparities. The Interim Constitution of Nepal of 2007 also recognizes basic education as a fundamental right 
and has made provisions for free education up to the secondary level.  
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  country  strategy  and  program  2005–2009  for  Nepalc  is  based  on  the  Government’s 
strategic  priorities  as  set  out  in  the  Tenth  Plan,  and  focuses  on  promoting  broad-based  economic  growth,  inclusive  social 
development, and good governance. The midterm review of the Country Partnership Strategyd in 2008 recognized the need 
for more strategic interventions in the sectors of ADB assistance to respond to the changing context of the country and the 
post-conflict environment. Education is the priority sector of ADB assistance to the Government.  

In line with the Government’s poverty reduction strategy and ADB’s assistance strategy, the Program will support government 
efforts in poverty reduction. It will directly support progress toward Nepal’s MDG targets in education. 

B.  Poverty Analysis                                       Targeting Classification: Targeted Intervention, Non-Income MDGs 

1.  Key Issues  

The Interim Constitution of 2007 provides the right to free education for each citizen up to secondary level. The constitution 
also  establishes  equity  measures  with  the  right  to  receive  basic  education  in  the  mother  tongue.  The  Tenth  Plan  (which 
embodies its Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper) also identified social development, including improvement in education, as 
one of the four pillars of Nepal’s poverty reduction strategy; and aimed at improving access to, and quality of, education. The 
Three Year Interim Plan further emphasizes inclusive education and the right to education for women, disadvantaged groups, 
indigenous ethnic groups (Janajati), and disabled groups, by increasing their access from primary to higher education. 

The Education Sector Program subprogram III will support the Government’s school sector reform (SSR) program for effective 
and quality education during FY2010–FY2012. The Program contains targeted intervention programs for inclusive education 
focusing  on  girls,  Dalits,  disabled,  and  disadvantaged  groups.  It  will  especially  benefit  girls  and  socially  discriminated  and 
disadvantaged  groups  by  providing  better  access  to  affordable  quality  basic  education—enabling  better  educational 
attainment and social capital needed for better livelihoods.  
According to the Nepal Living Standard Surveye the poverty incidence of Nepal reduced from 42% in 1996 to 31% in 2004. 
However, this decrease has been distributed unequally across development regions and different population sections of the 
country, resulting in increasing income inequality (Gini coefficient increased from 34.2% in 1996 to 41.4% in 2004). Poverty is 
closely  related to issues of geographic location, caste, and gender,; and there  are high levels of socioeconomic  disparities. 
Economic and social outcomes are worse in rural areas, particularly in remote areas. Poverty levels are highest and access to 
services lowest in the remote Mid-west and Far-west, with poverty incidence of 27% in the Western Region, 45% in the Mid-
western, and 41% in the Far-western regions. Among the people living in extreme poverty, agricultural wage laborers remain 
the poorest in Nepal (poverty incidence of 55%).  

The 11% drop in poverty is also distributed unevenly across different caste, ethnic, and minority groups. In the last decade, 
poverty  declined  most  significantly  in  upper  caste  groups.  While  poverty  declined  by  46%  in  the  upper  caste  Brahmin  and 
Chhetri group, it declined by only 21% among the lower caste Dalits, 10% among the hill indigenous ethnic groups, and 6% 
among  the  Muslims.  The  NLSS  II  data  show  that  the  poverty  incidence  of  historically  marginalized  and  socially  excluded 
groups—Dalits,  indigenous  ethnic  groups,  and  Muslims,  who  altogether  constitute  above  50%  of  the  total  population—are

education system, SSR is expected to contribute to poverty reduction.  

2. Design Features.  

Major  policy  strategies  for  inclusion  in  the  SSR  plan  consist  of  multilingual  education,  targeted  interventions  for  extremely 
marginalized groups and communities, flexible as well as decentralized approaches, and differentiated treatment to facilitate 
and integrate the populations with diversity needs. 

The SSR plan includes coherent implementation strategies, particularly in terms of reaching vulnerable communities. These 
include primarily the expansion of early childhood education and development (ECED) programs in poverty pockets, targeting 
the  children  of  vulnerable  groups;  promotion  of  education  based  on  mother  tongues;  and  enforcement  of  protection  of  the 
integrity of all children, with special focus on Dalits, girls, and marginalized populations.   

Free alternative programs such as nonformal education courses and traditional modes of education (Madarsa, Gumba, Vihar) 
will also be supported to be better equipped and capable to provide education to those not able to attend formal schools for 
different reasons. Apart from the above, incentives such as scholarships will be provided for children from economically and 
socially marginalized families. The reform will focus on girls and women, and children from educationally deprived groups so 
that they will participate equally and attain equitable results.

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

Social  exclusion  in  Nepal  takes  form  through  various  discriminatory  practices  based  on  caste,  gender,  ethnicity,  and  social 
and  economic  status,  including  other  parameters  of  vulnerability.  These  constitute  traditionally  deep-rooted  values  and 
convictions  that  affect  vulnerable  groups—especially  women  and  girls,  Dalits,  and  ethnic,  linguistic  and  religious  minorities 
through various discriminatory practices. Exclusion of children with disabilities is also traditionally embedded.  

It  is  estimated  that  8.1%  of  primary  age  children  remain  out  of  school—including  disadvantaged  children,  children  with 
disability,  children  facing  extreme  poverty,  working  children,  conflict  affected  and  displaced  children,  children  affected  by 
HIV/AIDS, etc. Despite substantial achievements made under the Education for All (EFA) program (2004–2009), children from 
vulnerable groups are overrepresented in the out-of-school population and remain a hard-to-reach group for reasons related 
to social distance rather than physical distance to the schools. 

Social exclusion also affects the teaching profession. The composition of teachers by major ethnic groups is disproportionate 
to  the  corresponding  population  figures—about  37.2%  Janajatis  and  15%  Dalits.  The  percentage  distribution  of  teachers  is 
3.7% Dalits, 23.7% Janajatis, 8.4% Madhesis, and 1.5% disabled.  

The  SSR  program  envisages  a  set  of  coherent  implementation  strategies,  particularly  in  terms  of  reaching  the  vulnerable 
communities. Policies and strategies for enhanced social inclusion and a range of actions, including inclusive education and 
affirmative  action,  have  been  adopted  in  the  Program.  These  include  financial  and  pedagogical  support  and  incentive 
schemes targeted to the schools as well as financial and in-kind support to families and children. Free alternative programs 
will be provided for students who cannot attend formal schools. Special provisions will be made to cater to the needs of public 
school students in Karnali Zone, one of the poorest areas in the country. SSR also provides for the recognition and support of 
caste  and  cultural  education  sources  like  Gumbas,  Vihar,  Madarsas,  and  Gurukul,  which  will  contribute  to  the  education  of 
children not attending mainstream education. SSR further intends to develop local content curricula, mother tongue materials, 
and instruction for early grades. Affirmative actions to increase the number of teachers from disadvantaged groups includes 
the  equitable  allocation  of  positions  for  the  recruitment  of  teachers  and  personnel  in  management  positions  from  these 
groups, and criteria for teacher selection weighted in favor of candidates from these groups.
